?def: A timeseries of MRI images like DCE perfusion, but using no injected contrast (uses flow coded pulses instead)
A type of MR image data set collected using at least three diffusion gradients of some factor 'b,' which is a function of the amplitude, duration, and interval of the gradiants.
Measures the functional connectivity between cortical and subcortical regions defined in the Desikan-Killiany brain atlas.
A type of MR image data set meant to capture volume and flow of blood in the brain.
The distance (in cm or mm) over which an MR image is acquired or displayed.
A measurement datum produced by an MRI machine prior to transformation.
Digital entity containing textual information or strings.
The plane that divides the body into left and right sections.
A type of functional MRI in which the participant is given a task or tasks, which are timed with the acquisition
T2 weighted image data set collected using a FLAIR sequence.
The refocusing of spin magnetisation by a pulse of resonant electromagnetic radiation.
Prescribed timepoints to collect in a 4D scan, results in in n number of volumes.
An MR image assessment to evaluate brain activity by detecting changes associated with blood flow in an evaluant.
A pair of MRI images pre- and post-application of an MT offset pulse
The process of locating a MR signal by altering the phase of spins in one dimension with a pulsed magnetic field gradient along that dimension prior to the acquisition of the signal.
An MRI acquisition sequence that acheives T2 weighting using gradient echo instead of spin echo.
The process of dividing voxels in a 3D space into any number of categories based on some criteria (e.g. contrast, signal intensity, location).
Parameters that a technician may specify to compose a specific MRI acquisition sequence as part of a scanning protocol.
T2 weighted image collected using a fast/turbo spin echo sequence.

The longitudinal scheme is designed to be unbiased with respect to any time point (TP). Instead of initializing it with information from a specific time point, a template volume is created and run through FreeSurfer. This template can be seen as an initial guess for the segmentation and surface reconstruction. The FreeSurfer cortical and subcortical segmentation and parcellation procedure involves solving many complex nonlinear optimization problems, such as the deformable surface reconstruction, the nonlinear atlas-image registration, and the nonlinear spherical surface registration.
Any combination of digital image analysis and statistical tools that may be used to derive processed brain images or data measurements about the brain.

T1 black holes are hypointense lesions commonly seen on T1WI in patients with multiple sclerosis, and indicates the chronic stage with white matter destruction, axonal loss and irreversible clinical outcome.
A set of digital data comprising some representation of an image using pixels (2D) or voxels (3D). Though typically displayed in 2D, the data may be arranged in an arbitray number of dimensions.
The MRI machine setting datum about the radiofrequency pulse sequence.
T1 weighted image data set collected using a spoiled gradient echo sequence.
Measures the functional connectivity between a set of predefined brain regions.
Measurement of axonal damage and the connections between brain regions caused by some neuropathological process.
An MRI acquisition sequence that uses a short inversion time to attenuate the signal from fat.

Siena estimates percentage brain volume change (PBVC) betweem two input images, taken of the same subject, at different points in time. It calls a series of FSL programs to strip the non-brain tissue from the two images, register the two brains (under the constraint that the skulls are used to hold the scaling constant during the registration) and analyse the brain change between the two time points. It is also possible to project the voxelwise atrophy measures into standard space in a way that allows for multi-subject voxelwise statistical testing.

We set out to develop and validate an LVV quantification tool for this purpose. Our goal was not to produce a method more precise or accurate than those described above. Rather, we sought to produce a highly robust technique capable of operating on clinical-quality T2-FLAIR images and producing results similar to more established techniques run on high-resolution scans. To do this, we extended an earlier idea for whole brain analysis proposed by (Baillard et al., 2001), and adapted it to LVV measurement on T2-FLAIR images. The core of our approach is a combination of multi-atlas segmentation and level-set refinement. We also extended the cross-sectional method for direct longitudinal analysis by including an optional Jacobian integration step. We called the resulting algorithm “Neurological Software Tool for Reliable Atrophy Measurement” - NeuroSTREAM.
Magnetic field variations applied to determine directional vectors that measure at least three dimensions of diffusion for a given voxel.
An inversion recovery (IR) pulse sequence is a spin echo or gradient echo pulse sequence preceded by a 180° RF pulse.
The setting datum of an MRI machine

Applies  RF  excitation  pulses  at  diff erent  phases every TR, so that the residual transverse magnetization has dif-ferent  phase  values  than  the  transverse  magnetization  most recently created.

The repetition time (TR) is the time from the application of an excitation pulse to the application of the next pulse. It determines how much longitudinal magnetization recovers between each pulse. It is measured in milliseconds. (radiopedia)
Radiofrequency pulses and gradients that result in a set of MR image data sets with a particular appearance.
The distance between two 2D image matrices, gives the measurement of a voxel in the z direction.

An MRI acquisition sequence that uses fast gradient echo sequences to collect a 4D data set corresponding to BOLD signal due to differences in magnetic susceptibility of oxygenated and deoxygenated hemoglobin.
T1 weighted image data set collected using an MPRAGE sequence.
A T1 image where gadolidium contrast agent has been used in the subject before image acquistion
A model-based subcortical segmentation tool.

An MR image that demonstrates differences in the T1 relaxation times of tissues. 

TR: short
TE: short
fat: bright
fluid: dark

radiopedia
Image data set collected at a later time than the evaluant's first scan.
The NeMo Tool uses a large reference set of healthy tractograms to assess implied network changes arising from a particular pattern of WM alteration on a region- and network-wise level.
An MRI acquisition sequence consisting of a magnetization preparation period followed by a rapid gradient echo sequence.
Neuroimaging technique used to estimate the volume of the brain.
An MRI acquisition sequence that using a spin echo sequence to accentuate T1 weighting.
Diffusion weighted image data set with at least 6 directional vectors.
T1 weighted image data set collected as one 3D volume using a gradient echo sequence.
T2 weighted MR image data set collected using a STIR sequence to suppress the signal coming from fat.
An image creation device that creates MR images
An MR image data set collected as a 4D time series representing changes in brain metabolism (i.e. BOLD), typically used as a proxy for brain activity.
Image data set collected at an evaluant's first visit in a study.
An MRI acquisition sequence that acheives T1 weighting using gradient echo instead of spin echo.
An MRI machine whose primary magnet has 1.5T of strength.
T1 weighted image data set collected using a gradient echo sequence.
Deep learning tool used to predict a lesion mask from either just a FLAIR or a combination of FLAIR, T1 weighted SE, T2 weighted, and PD scans.
A type of processed MRI image calculated as a results
An MRI acquisition sequence characterized by long TR and TE to accentuate T2 relaxation time of tissue.
A type of MRI image in which the contrast emphasizes density of protons, supressing T1 and T2 effects
A type of T1-weighted image in which the voxel size is no larger than x and anisotropy is no more than y
T1 weighted image data set collected using a spin echo sequence.
The total number of independent data samples in the frequency and phase directions (number of pixels in the frequency encoding - and phase encoding direction).

Produces some quantitative or qualitative data about voxels in an MRI data set that appear affected by some neurobiological process or as a result of some neurological disease such that there may be damage to the brain tissue.
The number of spin echoes in given unit of time.
A 2D, 3D, or 4D image data set produced by magnetic fields and radiowaves during an MR scanning session, typically to investigate the anatomy and physiology of the human body.
Measures the degree of diffusion weighting applied, thereby indicating the amplitude (G), time of applied gradients (δ) and duration between the paired gradients (Δ).

Quantitative measurement of brain size, shape, and temporal change (for example, in order to estimate atrophy) is increasingly important in biomedical image analysis applications. New methods of structural analysis attempt to improve robustness, accuracy, and extent of automation. A fully automated method of longitudinal (temporal change) analysis, SIENA, was presented previously. In this paper, improvements to this method are described, and also an extension of SIENA to a new method for cross-sectional (single time point) analysis. The methods are fully automated, robust, and accurate: 0.15% brain volume change error (longitudinal): 0.5–1% brain volume accuracy for single-time point (cross-sectional). A particular advantage is the relative insensitivity to differences in scanning parameters. The methods provide easy manual review of their output by the automatic production of summary images which show the results of the brain extraction, registration, tissue segmentation, and final atrophy estimation.
A type of functional MRI in which the participant is not given a task, but just rests during acquisision
The not measured distance between the slices.
A digital image that has been registered into another reference images space.
Generated by the frequency-encode gradient, except that it is used twice in succession, and in opposite directions.
A planned process that produces MR images from MR imaging datum.
Multiple echoes of different phase steps are acquired by rapidly reversing the readout or frequency- encoding gradient.@en
An MRI acquisition sequence that uses diffusion gradients to create contrast in the image corresponding to the Brownian motion of the tissue in the examined voxel.
Angle at which a proton's axis shifts from its longitudinal place to its transverse plane by excitation from radiofrequency pulses.@en

Based on preliminary experiments and established performance, we adopted a 3D U-Net semantic segmentation architecture for DeepGRAI. (Çiçek et al., 2016) The U-Net architecture is composed of two symmetric pathways – a descending contraction/encoding pathway which moves from low level voxel intensities at very high spatial resolution to abstract high-level features at coarse spatial resolution, and an ascending expansion/decoding pathway which moves from less localized high-level features to specific voxel classifications. Additionally, U-Net includes direct “skip” connections from the descending pathway into the ascending pathway, to provide the ascending pathway with low-level image feature information. In the current context, the descending pathway is essentially responsible for localizing the thalamus, and the ascending pathway is responsible for determining its precise borders.
A type of T2-weighted image in which the acquisition is performed using a 2D spin-echo technique
An MRI acquisition sequence characterized by short TR to minimize T2 weighting.

The echo time (TE) refers to the time between the application of the radiofrequency excitation pulse and the peak of the signal induced in the coil. It is measured in milliseconds. The amount of T2 relaxation is controlled by the TE. (radiopedia)

An MR image that highlights differences in the T2 relaxation time of tissues.

repetition time (TR): long
echo time (TE): long
flip angle: less important than with T1 weighting
fat: intermediate-bright
fluid: bright

radiopedia
Analyzes voxels in an MRI scan that appear as focal lesions in a T2 weighted scan.
The subject being scanned in an MRI study, and bearor of data derived from that study.
A measuement datum which is a data set that is made up of an n-dimensional array of elements (or entries).
The number of data points collected in one, two or all three directions. Normally used for the 2D in plane sampling.

FAST (FMRIB's Automated Segmentation Tool) segments a 3D image of the brain into different tissue types (Grey Matter, White Matter, CSF, etc.), whilst also correcting for spatial intensity variations (also known as bias field or RF inhomogeneities).
A functional assessment to determine the mapping of brain activity in an evaluant.
An MRI acquisition sequence that diminishes T1 weighting via long TR and T2 via short TE to produce images where voxel intensity corresponds to number of hydrogen protons in tissue.
The direction that the MRI image was taken.
An analysis examining the temporal correlation of activity throughout the brain.
The time elapsed between the preparatory 180° pulse and the 90° readout pulse.
An MRI machine whose primary magnet has 3T of strength.
An MRI acquisition sequence that uses multiple echoes produced by a train of 180 degree rephasing pulses with a high effective echo time to accentuate T2 weighting.
The plane that divides the body into inferior and superior sections.

The Configurable Pipeline for the Analysis of Connectomes (C-PAC) is a configurable, open-source, Nipype-based, automated processing pipeline for resting state functional MRI (R-fMRI) data, for use by both novice and expert users.
An MRI acquisition sequence that uses a long inversion time to attenuate the signal from water/CSF.
The plane that divides the body into ventral and dorsal sections.
FreeSurfer stream to derive surface labels and volumes from an invidual at only one timepoint.

FreeSurfer is a suite of tools for the analysis of neuroimaging data that provides an array of algorithms to quantify the functional, connectional and structural properties of the human brain. It has evolved from a package primarily aimed at generating surface representations of the cerebral cortex into one that automatically creates models of most macroscopically visible structures in the human brain given any reasonable T1-weighted input image. It is freely available, runs on a wide variety of hardware and software platforms, and is open source.
An assay that produces MR data about an evaluant.
The use of computer algorithms to process digital image data that produces some derived data measurement.
A neuroimaging technique used to estimate volume measurements (e.g. ml/mm^3) of a brain, its regions, a combination or regions, or a combination of similar cell types.
A timeseries of MRI images including pre- and post-contrast at different times
T2 weighted image data set collected using a gradient echo sequence.

A parameter that can be selected by a technologist as a percent of our overall field of view.\n\nA different field of view (the scanned region) in the frequency and phase encoding directions that means the data acquisition with fewer measurement lines.

The LPA was trained by a logistic regression model with the data of 53 MS patients with severe lesion patterns. Binary lesion maps of these patients were used as response values. As covariates a similar lesion belief map as for the LGA was used as well as a spatial covariate that takes into account voxel specific changes in lesion probability. Such a high dimensional model cannot be estimated by standard procedures, so we used a novel approach for fitting large-scale regression models, for details see here. The parameters of this model fit are then used to segment lesions in new images by providing an estimate for the lesion probability for each voxel.
